content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												Aliens vs Predator returns and, while the game gets some elements right, it's too bogged down in ancient game mechanics to be a winner. With three short, flawed campaigns for single players and a variety of passable multiplayer games, it's a lopsided production that will disappoint even the most ardent fan.The ProsExcellent character modelsAliens are fun to useMultiplayer is rather funThe ConsLooks like a 2010 game, plays like a 1999 oneInsanely frustrating control issues with targeting and kill moves.Marine campaign is completely uninspiredWay back in 1999, developer Rebellion finally made the dreams of sci-fi-loving gamers everywhere come true. They managed to develop a game based on the Alien and Predator film franchises that lived up to expectations. The first-person shooter captured the elements of each race in an exceptional way, and provided PC gamers with a thrilling blend of horror and action. Sadly, what worked over a decade ago doesn’t necessarily work now, and after playing Rebellion’s Aliens vs Predator reboot, it appears that they’re still partying like it’s 1999. Aliens vs. Predator We’re Mincemeat, Man!  That’s not to say Aliens vs. Predator is without merit. It’s still fun to scamper across darkened ceilings as a Xenomorph (the technical name for the Aliens), drop down on unsuspecting, terrified Marines and eat their brains. As a Predator, there’s still a sense of menacing satisfaction when tracking prey through the jungle, then jumping down and ripping their spine and head out. Even the uninspired colonial marine campaign has its moments -- especially near the end when some epic firefights occur.  But all in all, it’s only in fleeting moments where the game really thrives. The story unfurls like a continuation of the god-awful movies, in which Lance Henrikson plays the head of the self-serving and vile Weyland-Yutani corporation. Weyland (now basically cloned over and over) is utterly obsessed with harnessing the Xenomorphs and using them as a bioweapon to make his corporation rich. To that end, he’s using an entire base as his personal science lab.  When Weyland discovers an ancient Predator ruin, a signal is inadvertently sent out to the hunters to come and do what they do best. Aliens escape and chaos ensues; there’s not a shred of originality in the set-up. The game’s dogged use of standards from the movies—right down to all the same sound effects--is partially understandable, yet, ultimately, it feels lazy in presentation.  Three Sides to Every Story  As in previous games, AvP is broken up into three chapters. The human campaign is easily the worst. It has every tired, overused shooter cliché from the late ‘90s. You wake up alone, with only a useless pistol, while some faceless entity keeps barking orders at you. Worse, you don’t even get a name or a voice. Your character is just called “Rookie” and never speaks. He can only carry two other weapons, and his progress is completely linear. Humans always did seem extraneous in a war between the two ultimate sci-fi predators, but the developers seem determined to prove how weak and ineffective humans are here.  The Predator campaign is hardly an improvement in game design, and suffers from the same sort of linear pacing. What’s worse is that Rebellion has actually made the Predator feel wimpy. Although it’s hard to imagine, your Predator is weak, goes on the hunt barely equipped, and only gets new weapons as the story dictates. He also has to find energy sources to suck up to power his gear, which is a suspect game mechanic at best.  The Aliens are the most interesting species to play by far. The sheer joy of blazing across any surface is enough to give the Xenomorph campaign a leg up. Combat is problematic, but once you learn to properly hang to surfaces (hint: hold the button down all the time and you can move from surface to surface without hesitation), they’re just fun bugs to play as. It’s a shame the Alien campaign is the shortest at just about three hours, compared to four or five for the others.  All three species go over common ground as well, so expect to the see the same sights a lot. Aliens vs. Predator Kill Your Friends  The controls for both extraterrestrials are the biggest problem. Targeting in the game is simply sloppy. Since you’ll spend a lot of time in melee combat, the game ideally should have a targeting system that makes focusing on prey simple. Instead, you suffer through an impossibly twitchy targeting control that usually leaves you overshooting your enemies with your back exposed and no idea where they are.  Another severe issue is the use of fatalities. Both aliens can perform grisly death moves, but doing so locks you into an uncontrollable canned action for several seconds—more than enough time for any nearby enemies to kill you. While these moves are cool at first, there’s only a few of them and you’ll tire of them quickly.  Thankfully, there is multiplayer, and it’s entertaining in spots, but it won’t force you off any online shooters you might be currently playing. Pitting the three races in a variety of deathmatch and species-based games is generally fun. Each species has their own special game, such as Predator Hunt, a Juggernaut variant in which one player takes the role of a Predator seeking to hunt down opponents. If he gets killed, he’s replaced by his assassin. The Xenomorph version tasks a player with infecting all of the Marines on a map. Most of the multiplayer maps, much like the single player levels, are merely serviceable. There are two excellent co-op survivor maps, in which up to four marines battle endless waves of Xenomorphs, not unlike Horde mode in other shooters. The multiplayer is fun, but not deep enough to draw much lasting power for many players.Aliens vs. PredatorIn Space, No One Can Hear You Sigh  Aliens vs. Predator isn’t an awful game, but it is incredibly disappointing since Rebellion appears to have done so little with the source material . It’s a hard sell when there are significantly better shooters available, both online and offline. While the game isn’t a total loss, there’s just not enough here to make the game recommendable. As it is now, AvP is mostly a visually updated version of an eleven year-old game, and that’s not what fans of the franchises or first-person shooters deserve.

content:
Posted: January 24
												- Load game, setup video and other settings- Choose Marine campaign- Get through intro cut scenes and begin game- Looks good, feels good, I like what I see- Walking around for a little while , pistol at the ready - Eerily empty, quiet- Bagged my first Alien, he never stood a chance- Note to self - stop looking for items, nothing is here, or there, or anywhere (only the odd stimpak or magazine)- Very linear story and travel route, heavily scripted - feels mechanical - not instinctive or natural - wandering or veering off path results in verbal reminders of where you should be headed- First firefight, multiple aliens. Was impressed.  Those buggers crawl everywhere, walls, ceiling etc... and are hard to hit.  Maybe I'm just a crap shot- About half an hour into the game and I'm beginning to like it.  Guns handle well, ammo is in short supply for the Pulse Rifle and I keep running out and have to swith to pistol (infinite ammo for pistol)- Make sure I'm saving after each check point, just in case- Hit a tight spot and keep getting killed whilst trying to escape, waiting for a lift to open.  Again, scripted scene, hold off the Aliens until the door opens.  Try a few different strategies - I'm smarter than these Aliens- Each time I died I noticed that I was presented with an option to change difficulty setting - ignore it, I'm tougher than that, and there's no need I can do this- After my seventh death, at the same location and without much progress, I decide to change the difficulty setting from "NORMAL" to "EASY" - Don't judge me! LOL- Get a warning that this will "overwrite" the previous save.  What the hell, what's the worst thing that can happen?- Game restarts from the very beginning - Not good.  It never said "WILL RESTART GAME", only that my previous save would be "Overwritten".  Besides I still had a few saved games.- Look for one of my "Save" games - Nope, all gone, completely new game started, no way to go back to what I had before.- Start to wonder WHY I was given an OPTION to change the difficulty setting, if in fact the net result would end in a complete reset of the game- Overall, impressed with gameplay, graphics, sound and immersion.  Peeved at poor user interface and options, particularly an option to "Change difficulty", which doesn't expressly explain the consequences.- Not sure "IF" or "WHEN" I will have another crack at this game.  Invested around 45 minutes or so only to be reset back to the beginning because of a poorly worded warning.- There are better games, but if you're a cheapskate, like me, then pick this one up when it's on sale, it's a decent FPS. Can't give a real comment on the story, as I only got a little way in, but the acting and script I experienced were very basic and that's being charitable.

number of helpful: 2 of 14 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												This game is undeniably rubbish.This game doesn’t bother with the two AVP movies and has its own story line.The game consists of 3 campaigns, which sounds like a good idea, unfortunately they take place on the same 5 levels.The marine campaign consists of a generic FPS experience, they seem to try to make the game scary for the first couple of levels and then just give up on that and throw it all out the window.There are 67 audio logs that you can pick up and listen too, however if you are halfway through listening to one as you're playing through the story if a NPC makes any type of noise, the audio log will immediately stop playing, forcing you to start it from the beginning. The predator campaign also starts off on a good note, it's what you'd expect from a Predator campaign, jungle level, stealth, stalking marines, but once again, for some unknown reason the developers decided that the predator would be better suited to walking around small grey corridors.The Alien campaign is by far the worst, thanks to dodgy controls and a ridiculously short campaign, (I completed it under an hour on the hardest difficulty). The Alien latches onto every wall without you telling it too. There's a setting in the options menu that disables that problem, yet when you do disable it, it continues to do it anyway.Overall the single player is pretty god awful.MP:Well, the game has it's bog standard multiplayer modes, deathmatch, team deathmatch and a few lesser used modes. However there's no point talking about them because nobody plays them anyway.Team Deathmatch is the only mode people play. You choose between a marine an alien or a predator, there's no difference at all from their single player counterparts. Unfortunately there's some severe balancing issues. There’s no point being anything other than the Predator for one reason, the plasma caster, impossible to dodge and will kill in 1-2 hits, if it doesn't kill you in the 1st shot, you'll be knocked over, unable to move and then they'll fire immediately to kill you again.The stealth kill command is still in multiplayer, which just leads everybody trying to run behind your back and mashing the E key, because as long as the animation starts they get a kill. (Some cool animations though).This game is filled with glitches and exploits, such as spawning out of the map, to instantly fall and die, no spawn protection so people often kill you as you spawn and the Aliens use an exploit to kill you nearly instantly.Another thing this game does, you have to level up with an annoying EXP system (apparently every game needs this now. (I just hate it though)). The reward for leveling up isn't anything special and is indeed ridiculously pointless. You get skins for your character, on a first person game, Which obviously means you can't see them.Overall, the game is pretty appalling, there's honestly no point in spending any money on this game and you are better off spending it on something else.

Posted: May 6, 2016
												The amount of positive reviews on this title is laughable. I spent about an hour playing and just started laughing my♥♥♥♥♥off at how bad this game really is.. The maps are pretty lifeless. the rooms have nothing to look for and the path is very liner. It heavley relies on scripting every single event. nothing is a supprise. I didnt even feel like I was scared because I knew what was going to happen next and where the next enemy was going to come from. Now thats poor level design, and poor game mechanics. No feeling of being lost or not knowing where to go because your marker is always on the map and that ♥♥♥♥♥ is always telling you what to do. Its a basic hand holding game that the develpers thought was a good idea. Im really disappointed in the amount of bad design decisions in this game.The ai is really bad to. The zenos dance back and forth like its trying to find the best path to you, they get stuck on walls, or will sit out in the open wait for you to shoot them....Im sorry I cannot recommend this game, and anybody who actual does is lying to themselves, worst game ever played, hands down.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												The entire game was way too short. Especially when you consider it's file size. 9 gigs. 9 gigs of what? The graphics were pretty good for their time. But the game's very clunky and unrefined. It feels very rushed. I never even bothered with the Marine campaig. I DID have some fun playing as the Alien. It was challening enough to feel satisfying. Especially when you have to fight three predators. There was some nice attention to detail such as being able to see your 6 fingered limbs while you were climbing around. And the effect that the headbite had on enemies. But that campaign was also way too short and unrefined. Your goal seemed to be to return to the queen. And adding some more to that could've been interesting. But instead you move through levels with no idea what's really happening in the story and she suddenly gets killed and you replace her. Huh. Also it doesn't really make sense that the Alien should have health regeneration. Keeping the old mechanic of gibbing dead enemies for health would've worked fine here. It would've made the player more cautious, particularly on higher difficulties. And it also would've added some risky decison making when you were low on health and a possibly vulnerable enemy was nearby for you to replenish your health. It also would have made that final boss fight all the more satisfying once you were done with it. As for the Predator, the stealth's a nice touch I suppose. Same as it was in the 2001 AVP game. And you're not overpowered immediately playing as the predator as your healing and energy is limited. But the spear and smart disc made wading through areas filled with enemies a no brainer. Just switch between the two, heal occasionally and you're fine. That final boss fight was OK. Shame you can't really deal with it with melee like a proper predator might do (on higher difficulties that is) because of it's grab move and AOE attack. Back to the stealth though. The A.I are incredibly stupid. More so than they were back in 2001. They'll become alerted but won't really bother to pursue you. And it'll take them awhile to see you even when you're standing right in front of them. In AVP2 enemies would become alerted by this regardless of whether or not you were cloaked or not and regardless of difficulty iirc.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2012
												Play as the marines, aliens or predator in this updated version of the classic '99 AvP. The marines campaign offers the standard FPS game, you are given a motion sensor which will aid you in tracking where enemies are coming from. The Predator plays a bit more stealthily, you can cloak yourself to be invisible to humans but can still be tracked by aliens. Also your infrared can show you locations of the marines but not the aliens. You can distort and distract the marines to allow for easier takedowns. The aliens has no ranged attacks but they have the ability to move about freely anywhere on the map. You can climb walls and ceiliings get places you wouldn't even think of. Might be hard to find some online multiplayer games, but the campaigns themselves are well worth it.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												Developed at Rebellion by the team responsible for the original 1999 PC classic, the all-new Aliens vs. Predator allows players to take the role of three infamous species: Colonial Marines, Predators and Aliens. The game features a unique three-way online multiplayer experience, allowing gamers to battle for survival and the right to be crowned the deadliest species in the galaxy. Each race also has its own distinct action-packed single-player campaign mode, with a storyline that cleverly interweaves with the other two species’ paths. Set on planet BG-386; a human colonist mining group discovers an ancient pyramid containing a dark and horrible secret. Across the galaxy, a race of warriors is alerted to the discovery of their pyramid and a hunting party is dispatched to ensure that it remains sealed at all costs. Deep inside the ruined pyramid meanwhile, nature's deadliest species awakes from centuries of hibernation intent on finding new prey. The Colonial Marine's story is an incredible fight against all odds from horrors lurking in the dark. Surrounded on all sides yet armed to the teeth, the Colonial Marine represents humanity's last stand with the firepower to fight back. As the Alien, players discover what it's like to be the scariest, most murderous creature in the universe, with the ability to traverse any surface at lightning speed in order to get close enough to unleash its deadly claws, tail and teeth. A master of the hunt, the Predator grants the player an arsenal of exotic weaponry with which to stalk from the shadows. Earn the greatest honor by ambushing prey up-close, before butchering them for a gory trophy kill.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Most excellent coming off of Aliens: Colonial Marines.  Overall a well made game whose minor gripes are far outweighed by the great ambiance it conveys and graphics/AI that holds up well several years later.ATTN: This is mainly an explaination of my opinion of the Marine portion of the game and how it stacks up to the ill fated Aliens: Colonial Marines game.To be clear:I consider myself an avid Alien(s) fan and enjoy the Predator movies.  I did not care much for the AVP cinematic attempts.  I begrudingly accept Alien 3 and 4.  AVP 1 was the first game to truly terrify me and AVP to was one of my favorite examples of how a great story in a scary♥♥♥♥♥game can motivate playing through the fear.  Damn you Level 3 to this day.Now, AVP 2010:I first played this briefly on a rental on PS3 when it came out back in 2010.  I was playing in the afternoon in a sunny house.  I was not overly impressed with it then, but I also only played a few missions before returning it. Time passed, Aliens:Colonial Marines E3 demo happened.  I saw that and declared "That is what AVP 2010 should have been like!!"Now Aliens:Colonial Marines has come and gone and I very nearly spit on it, though I have managed to find a small amout of redemption in its DLC.  SMALL AMOUNT. But it had to be played.After that unpleasent experience, I have returned to AVP 2010 with a new perspective. And I tend to play it at night, in the dark, with the sound turned up as it should be.AVP 2010 is the younger brother of the game Colonial Marines should have been.  Marine mission-wise it excels at making you uncomfortable, remembering that hordes of slathering xenos are not so much terrifying as unpleasent when used to excess (CM), and using wisely the detailed environments and sound effects during well paced moments without combat that give you time to think about what's around the next corner and how low your ammo is.Marine-wise, this is where you must go to wash the stench of Colonial Marines from you.Alien and Predator missions are where it falls short of AVP2, losing some of the creativity and story telling excellence along the way.I wish we could lose the HUD and I would rather a motion tracker you had to check more like CM, but as an experience, AVP has what I was looking for, and that is to feel like a PBI grunt in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situation surrounded by nasty giant bugs wishing for a platoon of Ultimate Badasses that are never coming.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												i got this game for a small price (80% off?) back in 2012 and it hasn't been on flash sale since.before i go into detail, if you have a dozen or so friends who own this, get down and get groovy with it. If not? maybe pass.ok, detail time.its an HD remake of the old Alien Vs Predator game from 1999, where you play as Marines, Aliens, or Predators, and essentially murder everything that doesnt look like you. The gimmick is that they're all incredibly different; Aliens can run on any surface and see in the dark perfectly. Additionally, they specialize in impaling things that aren't looking at them. Predators do too, except they have that silhouette-type optical camoflauge invisible thing and spears/ninja stars/etc to give them an edge. Marines have motion sensors and guns that aren't stupid spears or acid spitthe campaigns are all really fun with different themes to them that make for a nice distraction but aren't exactly award-winning singleplayer games heremultiplayer's where its at, especially that one mode where one person is a constantly respawning alien and everyone else is marines huddling together to avoid the aliensall in all its pretty 7/10, maybe higher if you're able to play often with friends, since public online is completely abandoned in this game

content:
Posted: February 1, 2013
												Like anything branded Aliens vs. Predator you will find yourself playing mostly as a marine. As a marine you will understand what it's like to face off against hordes of xenomorphs or even face to face with a deadly predator. Your enemies are strong and dangerous and your guns tend to take more than a few shots to finish anything off. As a xenomorph you will hop on walls, crawl onto the ceiling and attack using stealth and misdirection for the few stages you get to play as one. The predator also gets shafted in terms of available levels, but you get to use tools and equipment you're familiar with from the movies. I couldn't get a multiplayer game going so I can't comment much on that, but the single player campaign is very fun, though it did leave me wanting more.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Is AvP the best game ever made? No. Is it a fun addition to the franchise? Yes. Is it expensive? Nope. Just don't buy the DLC packs — together they cost almost as much as the full game, and with no one on multiplayer there's no way you'll get your money's worth.Anyway, as a fan of the franchises involved, I had a lot of fun with the game. Each campaign is relatively short with only six missions, but it's almost like getting three episodic games. The way the events of each campaign are interconnected is really cool, and while each one tells a story on its own, they come together to make something bigger, and surprisingly leave room for what could be a really good sequel.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2012/03/aliens-vs-predator.html

content:
Posted: January 2, 2012
												Play as the marines, aliens or predator in this updated version of the classic '99 AvP. The marines campaign offers the standard FPS game, you are given a motion sensor which will aid you in tracking where enemies are coming from. The Predator plays a bit more stealthily, you can cloak yourself to be invisible to humans but can still be tracked by aliens. Also your infrared can show you locations of the marines but not the aliens. You can distort and distract the marines to allow for easier takedowns. The aliens has no ranged attacks but they have the ability to move about freely anywhere on the map. You can climb walls and ceiliings get places you wouldn't even think of. Might be hard to find some online multiplayer games, but the campaigns themselves are well worth it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Excelente multiplayer. O maior trunfo deste jogo é permitir que você realmente se sinta na pele de um alien ou predador. Jogando com o alien a jogabilidade muito mais se aproxima de um game de ação do que um FPS (first-person-shooter ou tiro em primeira pessoa), pois é possível correr pelas paredes e teto surpreendendo as presas especialmente em ambientes escuros, exatamente como um alien faria. Com o humano, o jogo é basicame um bom jogo de FPS, mas jogando com o predador, você tem um meio termo, pois ele é eficiente no combate corpo a corpo e se mimetiza com o ambiente, ao mesmo tempo em que possui armas de longo alcance. O modo single player basicamente serve como um tutorial para o multiplayer. Você aprende as habilidades básicas de cada espécie, para melhor utilizá-las no modo online. É curto, mas eficiente neste sentido.

												The idea of multiple campaigns one for each species is a great idea and single player was pretty fun. Multiplayer is also an interesting experience pitting each of the species against each other. However this games control system feels very cluncky at times and manuvering around the maps especially with aliens can be very disorientating. Multiplayer is also plagued by people relying upon the overpowered predators who easily over power the less advanced human and alien species. There is also the issue of executions i this game by sneaking up behind an enemy you can perform an execution which is an instan kill, but the catch is an execution performs a 3 second cinematic giving enemies plenty of time to kill you or walk behind you and perform an execution.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2011
												AvP is sorta fun. Akin to trying to ignite your farts, it gets old after a few minutes. Although everything seems fine at first glance, it's not until you play the three classes that you notice how one dimensional the gameplay is. The devs did a good job coming up with three unique experiences, but they did a horrid job of refining them. The marine class has shooting that feels clunky and dumbed down, the predator class has stealth and melee combat that feels less than intuitive, and the alien class has a wall climbing system with fast movement and cool instakills. I had the most fun with the alien class by far, though all the classes have awesome kill animations. The visuals are appealing, mostly because the lighting system was done so well. Despite the unique mechanics attributed to each class, the game is very bland. The multiplayer plays just like the single player, where the players are limited to class restrictions and therefore isn't satisfying at all. Oh well. 5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 27, 2011
												This is a consistent, but only mildly fun game. It probably won't be remembered as one of the best games of 2010, but it might be worth the cost if you enjoy the Aliens vs. Predator lore. This is one of those games where I neither felt disappointed or overwhelmed. It was just a solid title which will, unfortunately, inevitably be forgotten. Its most praiseworthy feature is the ability to play three short campaigns, each from a different perspective--one as an alien, one as a predator, and of course, one as a marine. The multiplayer does not live up to hype. Playing this game from beginning to end was a worthwhile endeavor, but I have no desire to repeat the experience. There are simply too many far better video games to choose from.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												An incredibly easy game to get into, and it sure is fun! Multiplayer especially. You choose from alien, predator, or colonial marine and fight it out with other aliens, predators, or marines. It also includes modes like Infestation, which is like Infection. One person is chosen as an alien and whenever the alien kills another player, they too become an alien and fight to turn everyone to aliens. Singleplayer is a little short, but consists of three completely different campaigns, one for each species. Marine and Predator each have 8 missions, while Alien has 6. Which is disappointing because in my opinion, Alien is my favorite species. I would definetely recommend buying this game!

content:
Posted: January 9, 2011
About The Game:Aliens vs Predator (2010) is developed by Rebellion & Published by Sega. It's a re-design of the older versions of the game.Aliens vs Predator (2010) is one of the final installments to the AvP franchise & it's also my favourite installment of the series, it's not perfect but it holds a place in my heart that couldn't be filled by the other titles.The Review:Aliens vs Predator is one of the most inovative & unique games around due to it's ability to throw 3 different class types & still manage to keep it "somewhat" balanced & exciting, this game plays very nice and feels like an Aliens vs Predator experience that it should be.Races Overview:Marine: The Marine is a humanoid race that is very weak & uses human created weapons, these weapons consist of all the weapons found in the movies & games previous to this game.The Marine is weak against both Races at close quarters or at a range, but the Marine does get a deadly arsenal of weaponry that make him a fearsom opponent to any who decise to tackle him head first.The Marine is stronger against the Aliens than the Predators but that's only because Aliens have to sneak up on him to get a clean kill & with the Marines motion tracker they're easily spotted & dispatched unless the Marine has slow witts.Predator: The Predator is an Alienoid race that's closer related to humans than to an animal, he's smart & agile, he's also very cunning & has a very large arsonel of deadly weaponary at his grasp which can destroy all opponents if they're not on the look out or quickly witted.The Predator relies in his Cloaking Device & his Mask Vision in order to track & stalk his prey but that doesn't mean that he can't defend himself, his weaponary consists of his famous Wrist Blades for close quarter combat against opponents dumb enough to get close to this monster.For those opponents at a distance thinking they can out shoot him, a devestating aray of hightech Alien weaponary,  The Combi Stick which can be stealthly used to toss at targets.  Disk Blades that will slice through any opponents skin & decapitate anyone who might be in the thick of it's way Plasma Caster that locks onto 1 target and barely misses, if it does miss then 9 times out of 10 you'll be knocked over & vulnerable to him for a few seconds.Predator is weak to Marines mostly because of his ability to track you whilst you're on the roam & the motion sensor that can pick you up at close range even if you're cloaked, as Predator relies on what he sees he is a good target for Snipers at a long distance to pick off rather than tackling him head first.Alien is a Alienoid race that is more closely related to Animals,  it has a humanoid body but it also has a tail with a long sharp blade on the end & it runs around on four legs, it also cannot talk making weird high pitched hisses like a snake does.Aliens are deadly when it comes to Stealth as they are dark black & can hide in the shadows, climbe on walls & hang from roofs with ease & if you think that is bad they're even worse in groups because of their speed & agility.Aliens rely on their ability to track scents through walls & floors so they can see you coming before you even know they are there, but because of their great sense of smell they are also at a disadvantage from any targets who are at a distance.Because Alien uses all fours to move around they cannot use weapons, so they are constantly at risk from targets who are hiding or shooting from a distance, Alien requires to be close in order to attack it's targets & so they're more deadly to a Marine than to a Predator but they're also more suceptible to the Marine due to his Motion tracker which means they need to rely on their ability to hide in shadows & wall climbing to get the drop on the Marine.The Alien's weaponary consists of it's long tail with the blade on the end, it's sharp claws that rip at your flesh & it's second mouth that's inside it's primary mouth in order to gouge out vital organs or eyes.Campaign Review:Aliens vs Predator (2010) features 3 seperate race Campaigns which are roughly 4 hours long and each connect somewhere along the lines ingame.It's unfortunate that all the levels are just redesigned for each class to make it feel different but it still all looks the same and is very farmiliar after the first playthrough, but this does not make it a great campaign to play through once in a while just because the gameplay is great.The 3 Campaigns you can play feature each race type: Marine. (Hardest Campaign & longest, that probably spans out to about 6+ hours, depending on difficulty level chosen)  Predator. (Shortest Campaign & easiest but it's still fun and can be completed in around 2 hours even on the hardest difficulty setting) Alien. (Moderately long campaign but EXTREMELY fun and my most favourite of all, this campaign takes around 3 - 4 hours to complete on the hardest difficulty setting).Each campaign is unique in experience because of the race you play, they might feature the same maps & area's but they're differently played with each race as you follow new paths to complete the objectives.The Campaign spans out over several different area's but unfortunately these area's are very lineir & get repetative getting from point A - Point B constantly.Campaign Rating:The Campaign gets a 5/10 rating because of a few factors:Campaign is fun for a few plays but gets boring pretty quickly.Due to the Campaign being quite long if you play all races it deserves praise but it also has a vast amount of flaws. Campaign lacks much story & that's a down point as well, Campaign really is just to familiaries yourself with the controls in order to play Multiplayer.The AI isn't all that smart & thus campaign is a breeze on the easier difficulties until you play Hard or Nightmare and even then it's mainly the bosses that kill you.Multiplayer Review:Now we get to the part of the game that makes the whole experience worth while & the whole game worth the purchase price.In Multiplayer there are a few different gamemodes: Deathmatch Species Team Deathmatch Mixed Species Team Deathmatch Predator Hunt Infestation SurvivorDeathmatch & Species Team Deathmatch are just as they sound.Mixed Species Team Deathmatch is just Team Deathmatch but instead of Predators vs Aliens & Marines you can have different species on your team fighting to be the best & win.Predator Hunt is a fun gamemode that is kind of like a Team game but it's also a FFA, the Marine team has to hunt down & kill the lone Predator who stalks them. In order to score points in Predator Hunt you need to be the Predator and kill Marines to get points & thus the person who is Predator the longest and kills the most people wins.Infestation is a game all about elimination much like Predator Hunt, except instead of Predators it's Aliens & instead of winning by kills you win by being the last Marine left after the team is wiped out, the idea of Infestation is for the Aliens to kill the Marines & the Marines need to stay alive as long as possible to become the last man standing.Survivor is much what it sounds like.The Multiplayer as it always has been in each AvP game is 100% amazing, and it's sad to say that it's quite underpopulated due to the lack of updates this game requires to make it to the point of playablely sound.Currently there is a number of bugs that make this game a chore to play online against other people with, High Ping & Stealth/Trophy Kill spammers make this game a nightmare because getting a kill is a breeze when these 2 factors come in.Multiplayer Rating:Multiplayer Recieves a solid 7/10.Do I Recommend This Game?: YESNo space to review.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												It's an ok game. The first person fistfighting, which isn't great, is forced prominently into the spotlight. Most painful are the 'trophy' and 'stealth' kills which are very slow. They might look cool before you've seen each for the tenth time time but they also disrupt gameplay and tend to allow for the enemy to gently remind you of their presence with bullets and claw whilst you , ignoring injury,  recite hamlet.The writing itself is average and i failed to see what was so amazing about bishop from the movies returning (other than the wasted budget). The marine versus android battles in the late game were awful and the three races have this absurd amount of durability to compensate for how slow they are. There are some things that are good; the multiplayer could be pretty scary if you were playing marine. The sound and atmosphere of some of the earlier levels were of high quality. The AI is better than expected (although worse than what could be hoped for) and some of the fights were both intense and fun. The game just doesn't  feel polished enough and the slower pace of the game doesn't work well in comparison to the faster AVP games from over half a decade ago. Recomendation: if you want a better AVP game; Try AVP gold or , even better, try 'AVP2'. It was made by monolith, the guys who made the first fear games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												AvP 2010 really lets you feel like you're a Xenomorph or a Predator. The story is throwaway, but decently executed. The graphics still hold up well, along with the sound. The gameplay is phenomenal: fun (and tough) AI, solid feeling abilities, excellent animations, good level design. All the little touches (acid/blood on the Predator's blades) and great sound effects make the game pretty immersive. What's not so great? The Marine campaign is noticeably weaker than either the Xenomorph or Predator, with goofy voice acting and limited scare value. Max graphics still require a decently powerful videocard to pull off (especially the DX11 effects) at high res (1080p+) at 60fps. Almost no one plays multiplayer anymore.Don't pick this game up expecting amazing writing. This game excels at giving you a sweet Alien/Predator experience, and an okay Marine one. If you are at all an Alien/Predator fan, definitely worth picking this up.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												If you want a nice looking AVP game and you hated the festering pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥called Colonial Marines, check this game out. Especially for under $5. The Marine campaign is intense and atmospheric which makes me scream like a pansy in fear. The only thing I wish for in the Marine campagin was that you had a squad, but that is what makes it scary. You are alone in the dark corridors fighting for your life, fending of xenos and facehuggers frantically. I wish the mulitplayer was still active, but the Single Player is worth your money alone. Get a friend to buy it with you so you can play the survival mode. For an AVP fan, this is a must buy. If you were disappointed with Colonial Marines (who wasn't?) then you should give this a shot. While it was mediocre upon its release, it is leagues better than the Colonial Marines♥♥♥♥♥♥heap Gearbox tried to sell us. Or, use it as a benchmark for your rig. The game is pretty graphically demanding. I am enjoying my time with it, so I would recommend it to someone who likes AVP or Sci-Fi shooters with horror elements thrown in there.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												This is a decent precursor to stealth titles such as Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Dishonored with similar mechanics and 'killshot animations' (like when you backstab someone in Dishonored or perform a silent takedown in DX:HR). The graphics hold up well (I played the DirectX 11 version) and it's pretty darn challenging. It really captures that motif and tone from the Alien Vs. Predtor series with dinghy, industrial environments full of ventialtion shafts, fans and dark corners that always have you on edge when you play as the human. The different arsenals and abilities for each species are good, though I did find that the predator and alien were too similar - both are a sneaky, fast-attacking, critical-hit playing style. Overall, though, I like and recommend this game. ****

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												As a complete noob when it comes to videogames of any scary sort (i cry and scream on easy mode for dead space) i must say that i absolutely love this game because it puts you in control of the monster, i would call this game almost a trainer or gateway horror game for those of us like myself who have no spine when it comes to horror. the three factions: alien, predator and marine might as well be difficulty levels themselves. personally i find alien to be the funnest, on easy mode you are an unstoppable beast much like in the movies, carving a bloody path through scientists and marines with nothing in your way, i can imagine the other difficulty levels are quite a bit more involved but easy alien is a bloody good time. Playing as the predator you still are high up on the food chain, but now you have to fight the xenos, which personally saw me go from gleefully laughing as i dismsmbered another scientist to screams of Wholy Fu**! and SHHHHH##@#$@ as i was flanked by xenos. i havent tried the marine campaign yet but neither am i too inclined to, seeing as having both the predator and alien against me, that battle rifle is looking pretty inneffective,Overall i see this game as being a good way to build up my spine for horror games, starting me off with putting myself in the aliens shoes, and ending with me being an invincible marine, in the mean time i think ill be playing this game with the lights on whilst screaming obscene amounts of profanity

content:
Posted: April 25, 2011
												If the title itself isn't enough of a reason to buy the game, you may just enjoy the diversity in the game as the races you choose more or less changes the whole gameplay experience. Plus the short-ish but quite well made campaign, and being able to join others in multiplayer and hunt around either as a group of predators, xenomorphs or a bunch of frigthened marines. That being said, marines can only have 2 weapons at a time, predators 4 and aliens none (as they're quite capable and deadly as they are) but aside from the default weapons you need to search for them in multiplayer. The maps are beautifully designed and the graphics are stunning. There are also many multiplayer modes to suit everyone's taste, and somewhat limited customisation options for all races (sadly no female marines). Worst thing about it would be the cramped server browser, you can look for Player Matches properly although can't join during the game, but Ranked Matches you just sign up for, seems random.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												This is my second time owning this game. As a big predator fan and also a fan of alien(s), this is one of my favorite FPS games still. I played this alot on the 360 when it was new but haven't had it for a couple years now. I was suprised to find a nice amount of people playing this online. It's really easy to jump into a match. The graphics for this game are still pretty good for todays standards, at least with the settings on max. I'm really glad I bought this game again. I'll be playing through all three campaign modes soon but for now I'm addicted to the MP. It might not have all the unlocks of a game like CoD or BF, but you can still gain ranks and unlock new skins for all three races. Also there are multiplayer and singleplayer achievments. I never played Aliens Colonial Marine but I've played pretty much every other game set in the universe of these two franchieses and this one is the best. If you are a fan of alien, predator and/or alien vs predator, I can't see any reason not to pick this up. If you arent a fan of the movies or other games then there may be better games for you but once you learn the basics of melee combat and get used to playing as each race, this is a really fun game. Also there is nothing quite like infestation mode; one player starts as an alien and the rest are marines. Once a marine dies they come back as an alien. If you get to be last man standing or get seperated it can be pretty intense trying to survive against 10 or more aliens an a big level. The pyramid from the 2004 AvP movie really captures the atmosphere of being trapped in a moving temple all alone. 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2012
												Aliens vs Predator, christ on a cracker.. You all know the concept that has been hack-murdered and overly used a million times for almost three decades now. Well here's one more for the money hungry industry, set like the last AVP game from 99' in where you play as both and the humans. Ironic I think that the human's campaign is the longest even though their name isn't in the title. Speaking of the title, aren't they both predatory alien species.. thats a bit of a mess. Either way, the Human Campaign is the longest and after the first 25minutes nothing more than a generic FPS.The Predator campaign had me squeeing like a japanese school girl as I lept from tree to tree cloaked using the prey I hunted ex-comrade's dying screams to lure them out into the clearing.And finally the Alien mission was the shortest, simpliest and well, most disoriented. I found it annoying going from floor to ceiling constantly in the dark to the point I was motion sick and confused. Buy if its on sale

Would definitly recommend if you are an AvP fan!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												As a complete noob when it comes to videogames of any scary sort (i cry and scream on easy mode for dead space) i must say that i absolutely love this game because it puts you in control of the monster, i would call this game almost a trainer or gateway horror game for those of us like myself who have no spine when it comes to horror. the three factions: alien, predator and marine might as well be difficulty levels themselves. personally i find alien to be the funnest, on easy mode you are an unstoppable beast much like in the movies, carving a bloody path through scientists and marines with nothing in your way, i can imagine the other difficulty levels are quite a bit more involved but easy alien is a bloody good time. Playing as the predator you still are high up on the food chain, but now you have to fight the xenos, which personally saw me go from gleefully laughing as i dismsmbered another scientist to screams of Wholy Fu**! and SHHHHH##@#$@ as i was flanked by xenos. i havent tried the marine campaign yet but neither am i too inclined to, seeing as having both the predator and alien against me, that battle rifle is looking pretty inneffective,Overall i see this game as being a good way to build up my spine for horror games, starting me off with putting myself in the aliens shoes, and ending with me being an invincible marine, in the mean time i think ill be playing this game with the lights on whilst screaming obscene amounts of profanity

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												It's not that bad. Graphics are still great even now. The gameplay is also tense and satisfying. Although you will find that some of the more modern gameplay conveniences are not there (regenerating health/quick ironsights aiming), you'll forgive it when you shotgun an alien at close range and it actually hurts you with its acid blood. Also, the Aliens are REALLY good at hiding and waiting for just the right moment to lunge EVEN IF YOU ARE LOOKING RIGHT AT THEM.My experience:-Dark room.-Motion tracker beeps-Start twirling around frantically to find it-"Must be in the vents"-Hide in a corner so they can't sneak up on me-Alien(s) pop(s) out.-Empty entire pulse rifle-Need a few hours to calm down7/10, I almost feel as awesome as Ripley.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2011
												Don't let the philistines who are stuck in the past deter you. As shooters go this is probably good enough to be GOTY 2010.A great melee system lend much needed depth to brawling. The three seperate but interveawing campaigns are all excellent gameplay and story wise. A rare combo. It really puts you in the Aliens universe unlike anything since the original film, but with a healthy dose of Predator.Even the dreaded sync kills aren't that bad and help expand the melee system. It isn't always a guaranteed kill and it's possible to break free in certain cases.Everything seems to work well and it looks nice to boot. If you enjoy aliens, predator or just shooting stuff with homing bullets this is one not to miss.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												I have completed the Alien and Predator campaigns and they are ok. The Marine campaign I have played a bit of and it is really boring; a crude generic FPS without any really engaging features. The Marine campaign definitely feels phoned in.As for the Predator campaign, weak melee controls let it down and with the combi stick as only a ranged javelin and your claws as the only melee weapon, it feels as if something is missing. There is your typical shoulder blaster etc, but everything feels a bit cluttered. For the most part you do feel like you are playing as a Predator, but equally it does not exactly grab you with appealing controls.The Alien campaign, however, saves this game if you can get it on sale. It is incredibly short, which is a shame, but has very solid stealth gameplay and you feel the brutality of the Alien. The wall crawling suffers in first person and from rather glitchy controls and getting stuck on lights and wall/ceiling (or floor) edges. This is, however, easily mastered with a bit of practise.I have tried the multiplayer rarely, and that was mostly early on in the game's history. It has always been underpopulated, even then. It was not especially brilliant, and lacks any structure which saves the singleplayer from utter dull chaos!For the Alien campaign I give it 8/10.For the Predator campaign I give it 6.5/10.For the Marine campaign I give it 4/10.Overall I give it only a sad 6/10.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												What I write about MP is based on two weeks.Pros: cool designs. You get to do a lot of Alien, Predator, and Marine stuff. The three are relatively balanced. The melee, though awkward, works pretty well.Cons: Bare bones as far as content goes, with almost no weapons, features, maps, etc. In spite of dedicated servers, there are usually two, or as little as one, server with players on. Hardly anyone plays anything but Species Deathmatch, and that one does get old. SP gets monotonous within minutes. The story is boring, the three endings unsatisfying, and they have the gall to hint at a story far more interesting than this one... if you can tell a good story, Rebellion, then how about following up on the great one Sierra gave us? Short campaigns. Rushed. Lazy. Wall-Crawling doesn't always work.For SP, play the first two games again. The MP of those two is more or less dead, so... for MP, L4D2 is far more fun, distinct, varied, etc. than this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												For all two of you reading the reviews for this older game, I promise AVP is worth the $3.50 I paid for it. Players control the marines, Predators, or aliens in separate but interwoven campaigns. Each race behaves differently and requires a unique strategy to master. The marines follow a pretty standard (but enjoyable) first-person shooter model. The Predators use a combination of hand-to-hand and stealth, but also employ a number of high-tech gadgets, like laser cannons, proximity mines, and cloaking fields. The aliens are the most mobile of the three and use speed, stealth, and their ability to climb on any surface to get the drop on their foes. All three races battle each other in a storyline that basically doesn't exist but doesn't need to. Aliens bite through human skulls and Predators get mowed down by the pulse rifle, and it's awesome for any fans of the franchise. The campaigns also offer a nice variety in the enemy department. Unfortunately, a few blemishes mar this otherwise great game. Firstly, the multiplayer is dead. That's a shame, because the game was designed with a great balance between the three races that would have made for fast and furious team death matches. Secondly, while it's great to play as the aliens, I found a lot of faults with their campaign. I don't personally get motion sickness from games, but anyone who does will want to avoid playing as the Xenomorphs. Their ability to speed across any surface can be dizzying at times. I found myself having trouble adjusting to fully three-dimensional thinking, and some players might dislike the fact that the ceiling and walls can also be the floor. The aliens' full-spectrum vision made the world look a little cartoonish, and their campaign was simply too limited. It's much shorter than the other two, probably intentionally. The aliens can only slash with their claws and tails, so combat becomes repetitive. Allowing the player to control a spitting Xenomorph or a Queen for a few levels might have added some variety. Too bad the developers neglected to do that. Lastly, the Predator acquires a spear later in his campaign that's REALLY over-powered. I had to actually force myself to use other weapons to make the fights more fair. Overall, though, the game is fantastic for any AVP fans. All the sounds from the movies are in full use here, and it's great to play with human and Predator technology. It's definitely worth the bargain price. 8/10.

												Single player is awesome. Multiplayer is♥♥♥♥♥♥ If you think its going to be an avp2 experience, look away my friends, look away.Predators are overpowered. Expect games where predators outnumber both aliens AND marines combined. Not as rare as one might think.You might be thinking "Oh, i'll be going alien, surely since its a melee only class i must have an advantage in close combat, or at the very least, a teeny tiny advantage." HAHAHAHAHA!Nice balance.The entire combat premise of this game is a ♥♥♥♥ing rock-paper-scissors farcical. Light attack beats heavy, block beats light and heavy beat block.As expected, heavy does more damage + has a longer casting animaton. BUT, you can actually CANCEL the animation by blocking! So you can make it look like you're going to heavy attack, and then immediately transition to a block! WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ DOES THIS EXIST?What is the ♥♥♥♥ing point of creating a rock-paper-scissors mechanic if you are going to radically change the entire god damn premise of it?The previous avp games were filled with intense fast paced multiplayer action! And this one is just, disappointing. If you are going to have a rock-paper-scissors combat, ♥♥♥♥ing do it properly! God!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												   For 15€ you get 3 campaigns : Marine, Alien and Predator. The Marine mission is very tense, as you make your way trough the dark corridors and suddenly you hear footsteps on the roof getting close to you.The Alien campaign has some stealth elements and you are able to hide in the dark and climb walls (though you'll get a little dizzy at first).  The predator campaign, my favourite one, is more stealth based, as you'll become invisible, distract enemies, jump on high structures and kill your enemies one by one. It is al ittle short, I'll admit it, but it has a multyplare component (which I haven't really played). Also another thing that bothered me is that all three campaigns tell the same story.    Alien vs Predator is a good game to wash away the bitter taste from Aliens Colonial Marines, i really recommend it.     75/100

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Let me get this straight. The game isn't bad. Rather, it seems reasonably good. My problem is more with the multiplayer than the singleplayer, however I do dislike the Marine campaign.The multiplayer to this game is next to DEAD, with one or two lobbies at a time, with one or two players. The quick-match doesn't work, because you need to get a full set of players for it to begin. The server browser shows the couple servers there are, but these servers are nearly empty. Couldn't even get into a single match to see whether or not it was good, so I guess it's not.I only did a little of the Singleplayer, and got about half an hour into the Marine campaign. It started well, good atmosphere, ok controls (could be better, but not bad), and aliens showing early in.  However it quickly ramped up the difficulty, and got me to a point I could not pass. Again, I only played HALF AN HOUR, and I could not get by a part. This was on NORMAL difficulty, I might add. I might understand more if it was on hard, but it wasn't. I was getting instantly cornered and killed by 2 or 3 aliens when I had to wait for the stupid elevator. That's when I quit. That's when I decided it's worth refunding.5/10 probably WAS good, but ISN'T good anymore.

Posted: September 24, 2015
												Been a big fan of the Aliens series, and to be honest I only bought this game because of how much I enjoyed the previous title, but I'm not a big fan of the Predator, and I never played the Alien much, but was amused at getting the chance to play the Alien creature, gave me a few giggles along the way.I didn't enjoy this title however as much as I did the previous game, because they took out the Skirmish mode that I had so much fun with in the previous title, and was reliant more on the Multiplayer aspect, which was not really fun to be honest, unless you like a life expectancy of 30 seconds, when pit against the Predator and his high tech weapons, and vision modes.  Space Lizards never scared me anyway, thats why I personally don't believe the Predator belongs in the Alien Universe.   So the Predator hunts the Alien, but the Space Jockies created the Alien, so at what point did the Predator meet the Alien, and at what point did the Space Jockey say, "If you have a problem with my dog, you have a problem with me!", so what I'm saying is, "Were the Space Jockey's aware of the hunting habits of the Predator?"  Where does this story line fit in?Anyway, the game was fun to play Singleplayer, but the campaign was too short, if your bored, and are an Aliens fan, I'd buy it just for the Alien, and give yourself about 4 or 5 hours of gameplay, otherwise, you'll be stuck to getting killed over and over and over again in laggy multiplayer sessions, and being stuck to buying their overcharged DLC content, which doesn't give you much, compaired to the prices they're charging you.I suppose your just buying the logo's when all is said and done!I rate this game 6.0/10 - Gave them the massive penalty for shore campaign and removal of skirmish mode.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Great game! This game was actually the first game I bought on steam. But that aside, this is a nice game! The best part about it in my opinion is the fact is has 3 campaigns: Marine, Alien (Xenomorph) and Predator. Let's start off with the marine campaign:In the Marine campaign you play as Rookie (what a surprise) who's squad is killed in a Xenomorph ambush. Basicly, you're on your own for the biggest part of the campaign. You will find other marines from time to time, but they usually don't last very long. It is a funny campaign since you have 3 'boss fights' in it: The Xenomorph Queen (ironicly the first and easiest one), the battle with the Predator and the battle with Wayland. There are some different weapons you can choose but for the most part it's a general FPS with the addition of aliens and the motion tracker.In the Alien campaign you play as Specimen 6, one of the colony's guinea pig Xenomorphs. Unlike the 2001 version of this game, you start immediately as a fully grown Xenomorph. Your goal is to break out and kill humans, and eventually predators. Very cool campaign, unfortunately it's the smallest one. The fact you can walk on any surface is also nice, and the stealth kills and finishing moves are both amazing and gory. Be aware of the androids btw, they're very dangerous...Finally in the Predator campaign you have to hunt down the Abomination (it's basicly a Predalien). To do this, the Predator has an awesome variaty of weapons at it's disposal. The plasma rifle is overpowered, the mines are too, the smart disk can be difficult to handle with fast moving targets and the spear as well. The cloacking, stealth and the different visions really add to the feeling of the predator campaign. Once again the stealth kills and finishing moves are both amazing and gory.There's also a multiplayer in the game with many gamemodes that barely anyone plays. Seriously, 95% of the games are Team Deathmatch or Mixed Team Deathmatch. They are fun, don't get me wrong, but it can be repetative to do the whole time. Also by playing matches you can level up and unlock new skins for your Marine, Alien or Predator.All in all, very good game, nice graphics and lovely 3 different campaigns. Get this game if you enjoy the different play styles it offers or if you just love the Alien and Predator universe! :)P.S. I haven't really seen anyone play the DLC maps, so I don't know why they're there :P

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												Dissapointing Alien campaign and the dead multiplayer means that, outside of sales, this should only be for hardcore fans.Let's start with the story: Aliens vs Predator isn't a movie tie in (thank God) but a separate story. On an unknown planet, Weyland Yutani has been experimenting with Predator technology, and with the aliens. As a result, aliens break loose, and run rampant across the planet, killing most of the Weyland Yutani employees. Colonial marines are sent in to clear up the mess, but Predators have also landed, killing half of the marines before they even make planetfall. A four way war between the Marines, Weyland (for some reason) the Predators and the Aliens breaks out. Three campaigns, with separate beginings and endings. Who shall triumph?+Very good Predator campaign+Good graphics for the budget+Good atmosphere/OK marine campaign-Dissapointing Alien campaign-Dead multiplayer-Dissapointing last man standing4/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2010
												This game has some real potential. The graphics are great, and the sound is pretty good, making one of the best atmospheres in the franchise. You will need a good system to play this smoothly. I highly recommend playing at least the first Single Player Predator mission to get a feel for the Predator play mechanics. It takes a little getting used to. The interface is a little clunky and the Predator is not as easy as one might think because all the weapons need to be found (except the blades) and the play mechanics are a bit unfriendly to a noob. There are only a few maps. More maps would add MP playability. I would recommend the map packs and then more people might play the game. But the map packs are too expensive for just maps. There is no crouch which is a must in any FPS. One of the most satisfying things about this game is the stealth and trophy kills that one can have  by a certain amount of cunning and practice. At $19.99 I highly recommend this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												This is a decent precursor to stealth titles such as Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Dishonored with similar mechanics and 'killshot animations' (like when you backstab someone in Dishonored or perform a silent takedown in DX:HR). The graphics hold up well (I played the DirectX 11 version) and it's pretty darn challenging. It really captures that motif and tone from the Alien Vs. Predtor series with dinghy, industrial environments full of ventialtion shafts, fans and dark corners that always have you on edge when you play as the human. The different arsenals and abilities for each species are good, though I did find that the predator and alien were too similar - both are a sneaky, fast-attacking, critical-hit playing style. Overall, though, I like and recommend this game. ****

												I honestly think this game is seriously underrated.Pros- Great story- Great atmosphere- Fun boss battles- Survival is a blast to play- Some fun multiplayer modes- Alien gameplay is AMAZING- Predator gameplay is OP- Marine gameplay is alright for the most part.- Multiple marines, aliens, and predators to play as or unlock for the multiplayerCons- You'll be by yourself 99% of the game in the Marine campaign- Multiplayer is pretty dead- The predator is OP in multiplayer and ruined it really. If you manage to get into a multiplayer lobby you'll be put is matches that are like 5 Predators vs 2 Aliens vs 1 Marine. - No co-op, which would've been great for the human campaign.- lots of content is in DLC. Without the DLC you'll only have 2 survival maps to play on.- No RPG element as the Marine. You're pretty much a typical CoD rambo. Plus your motion tracker is apart of your hud, instead of it being a thing you actually hold to use like you do in Aliens Isolation and Aliens Colonial Marines which kinda breaks the immersion and horror element of it.Rating: 7/10

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I remember when the Predator was over powered and the aliens were the main enemy and the marines were just there. Now the Predator is weakened and a marine can just shove you on the ground even though that's basically the same thing as a man throwing a lion to the ground. The online is fun until you realize how much needs improving. Every character has something to counter the other except..the predator. His gadgets can only do so much with everyone killing you with a one-shot shotgun blast I mean really who wants to play Aliens vs Predator just to play as the Marine grunts. Now that is 75% of the remaining players. Out of a 18 player lobby you'll find 5 Predators. 10 Marines, and just 3 Aliens. This game was fun when it came out because of diversity but it's just a shell of what it was. It needs to be re-visited but Rebellion won't make another avp for a long time so enjoy the last remnants of a dying franchiseOverall 5/10>The campaign is fun but very short and two hours with each character is barely a game>Online activity is dead except for a few people maybe like 50 in total>One shot kill marines are generally the hackers in the game. One shot pistols are lovelyThey should re-name the game to Marines vs the world...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Marine Campaign: 7/10Could do without the modern-shooter complex, and noticeably streamlined in mechanics for mainstream appeal, but does the job of making you feel like a squishy human against virtually impossible odds. Atmosphere and gameplay variety at its best.Alien Campaign: 5/10Feels like there was some lost love with this one. Playing as an Alien drone decimating hardened marines loses its novelty before long, and you wonder what happened to the "Aliens" in the title, which is the main constriction of this campaign, in my opinion. First-person executions are fun, but first-person gameplay feels clunky on keyboard and gamepad, with or without aim assist.Predator Campaign: 6.5/10The middle child. First-person gameplay is more seamless, but melee combat is shallow and clunky, although the variety of projectile weapons balances it out somewhat. I felt like a Predator, and had fun doing it, so no harm done. Also the most engaging story of the 3.Multiplayer: Dead/10Overall: 6/10The Aliens and Predator franchises having a crossover is a dumb, fun idea, and this is a dumb, fun game. What should have been changed and what should have stayed on from the original 2 games is something I'll look into someday. A more engaging story would have been nice, but better gameplay is always the priority.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												A great game that I played repeatedly on my PS3, I got it on steam to see if it was as fun as I remember it being.It was.The predator campaign is fun, but overall I would consider it the weakest of the three. Stalking marines is fun but eventually the stealth approach wears thin, and the melee combat is clunky (and ridiculously difficult on hard mode, let alone nightmare).The strongest campaign is probably the marines, as nothing beats that for sheer claustrophobic tension as you make your way through dark tunnels and corridors, always dreading the sound of your radar beeping, only to break out in a cold sweat when it stays silent for too long.My favourite campaign, though, has to be the alien. It's like playing as the monster form a horror movie. Forget 'Evolve', if you want to be the monster, then play the alien campaign. Not just any monster, the but the most iconic monster ever the grace the cinema screen. Nothing compares to picking off marines one by one and listening to them slowly panic.Love it.Get it.Play it repeatedly.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Now that I've had a chance to play through all three campaigns, I can heartily recommend this game.For starters, it looks gorgeous.  Visually it holds up very well considering how much graphics have advanced in just the pasts five years.  Sound effects are spot-on and the music is good too, although a bit repetitive, and there are moments when the ambient audio is a little too heavy-handed.Gameplay is solid too.  The Marine plays exactly as you'd expect, not that that's a bad thing.  Also, easily the most terrifying campaign.  Even after the initial playthrough, the Xeno AI is good enough to constantly keep you on your toes.  The Predator layers on a lot of very cool mechanics that make you feel like the ultimate badass.  Both campaigns are very atmospheric and offer a couple really nice set-piece battles.The Xeno campaign is perhaps the weakest.  Playing as one remains quite disorienting and the human AI is frightfully stupid; you can clear out a whole room by drawing Marines one at a time into the same dark corner.  Both the Xeno and its story move so fast that I often finished missions before even realizing it.  It picks up right at the end, no spoilers, but it's too little too late.Once you gather all the collectibles in each campaign, there's no longer any real replayability, so how much you get out of this game will largely depend on whether you invest in the multiplayer community.  That's not really my scene, but I can easily see how playing as any of the three character types with friends would be a lot of fun.For hardcore franchise fans, this will be a great treat.  For general FPS fans, there's a lot of variety here to keep you occupied for a while.  If you're at all curious, AvP is well worth picking up on sale.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												Aliens VS. Predator is a wonderful remake of the original game made in 2000 "Aliens versus Predator."The gameplay is amazing, and the graphics were definitely kicked up alot. There are a few problems, and I'm just gonna go over some pros and cons I have for the game.PROS:-There are 3 diverse characters with their own story.-The fps setting creates fear around you as you play.-The controls and gameplay are really fun.-The levels have amazing design and are challenging.-The game is just really amazing when it comes to overall performance.CONS:-The game's multiplayer adaptation is dead. There is about 1 server every once in a while with 6 people on it. If it would come back, this'd be my favorite game.-The controls could become confusing at times depending on what you're using.-It seems as if one class is stronger than another creating a feeling of rage. This normally is only in multiplayer.-Every NPC looks like a child molester.Once again these are only ones I gathered, but there are plenty more pros and cons. But yes, this game is worth playing unless you buy it for multiplayer.

												A mixed bag in this one.  Campaigns are more like tutorials but you may find yourself having fun in them if you are a fan of the lore.  Multiplayer is a lot of fun if you can find players, a lot of the customers abandoned this game around launch since patches weren't being put out to fix critical bugs.  Instead they put out the first map pack which was like a punch to the face for the loyal fans that were wanting a playable game before DLC.  Now the game is pretty much cleaned of bugs and a small portion of the player base is still kicking around on some servers.  With the cut-down price this game is worth it for the entertaining multiplayer and source material.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												For those who are into the Alien/Predator shared Universe, the game has a lot of good stories. It makes both Aliens Vs. Predator movies seen like child's play.The best thing from this game is that it makes you go back to the classical Alien and Predator. It makes you fear them, makes you feel tense while playing, having to pay attention to everything around you.But there are many drawbacks to this good story.Once you get the mechanics of the game, killing Aliens and Predators alike becomes easy. Around the third/fourth marine mission, you have the (personal) option of going commando style for playing the game or roleplaying a real marine, like I did (by the way, doing so helped make the game better).Playing as a Predator or as an Alien poses no real challenge for those who are already accostumed with classical FPS games.The finishing moves from Aliens and Predators alikes gets repetitive somewhere around their respectives "second mission".For those who have played the first Aliens Vs. Predator FPS in 1999, this game is nowhere near the classic game. As for fans, this game gives some real good insights about their story together.My main though on this game is that it seems that they started really well on this one, with the first missions being really awesome. Then, probably they had some time restraints imposed to them and had to rush their work, because the last missions only go downhill from the first ones, with the notable exception of the Predator plot (I'm not talking about the gameplay here, only the story).Score:For Alien/Predator fans: 7,5 in 10For the rest of the people: 6 in 10NOTE: I was not able to play the multiplayer, since I couldn't find any more games, so I'm not able to evaluate this mode of play (for now, at least). As for the survivor mode, it is "nice" (would give a 7), but since I couldn't play the cooperative mode, I am not able to properly evaluate this mode of playing.WORTH BUYING? Yes, IF it on sale on Steam.DON'T: Buy this game if you're into playing it multiplayer.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Short, but sweet. Aliens vs. Predator is a brutal FPS from Rebellion. Let’s have at it.The GoodI remember waiting for this game to release like it was going to be a second Christmas that year. While, my expectations were definitely a bit high, the game, nonetheless, was pretty awesome. Playing as the Predator is always a blast. Tearing people’s skulls out with the spine still attached never, ever gets old. Similarly, impaling people Vlad the Impaler style as the Alien is entirely too fun. The executions in this game could go toe to toe with Mortal Kombat fatalities any day of the week.The game offers you three campaigns to play through, all of which are roughly set within the same story line. You may choose to play as the Predator, the Alien, or as a Colonial Marine. I’ll let you guess which one is the least entertaining. (Hint: It’s the Colonial Marine).The BadAs I mentioned above, the least entertaining campaign to play through is the Colonial Marine campaign. Much to my chagrin, it is also the longest campaign. In a game in whose name they are not even mentioned, the CMs got the most screen time and it honestly kind of bothers me. Not only that, but the CM character can barely jump and the flamethrower is practically useless.The MehA lot of the Predator’s cooler gear is unlocked late game and you won’t have a chance to use it again in the earlier levels. A New Game+ option would have been very much appreciated. There were so many people who needed a Combi-Stick through the rib cage who will never receive one.The Alien can be a bit trying when it comes to movement. She is very fast and borderlines on almost too maneuverable. I often times found myself climbing onto walls accidentally and then couldn’t respond in combat. This lead to my untimely death on a few occasions as the Alien is squishy and meant for stealthy play.Verdict: YeaIf you’re a fan of either the Predator or Alien franchises, you’ll probably like this game. You can rest assured it wasn’t anywhere near as terrible as Aliens: Colonial Marines was. If you see this one go on sale, it’s very much worth a playthrough. As always, thanks for reading.

												Visually, this is a very impressive game. It plays well, but the story is very short. There is fun to be had, but only in select moments. Also, the technology of the predator is a little flimsy, as evidenced by the sloppy control of the shoulder cannon. The classic AVP implemented the device in a much better way, allowing for the characters to fire the weapon after aiming with the laser, which in AVP 2010 comes on when you fire the weapon, after the HUD targeting display appears.The Alien campaign is good and the Alien physics are admirable, although in reality the alien would be able to swipe with both hands. The other games in the series took note of that, but it looks like the new one decided to ignore that fact. Still, it is most impressive to play as the alien and the executions are most shocking and invigorating at once. I will play the Marine campaign sometime and complete this review. I do this because AVP 2010 was a good title that offered too little and failed to refine some of the technical basics of the player characters.
